title: Zoom
summary: A former superhero (Allen) is called back into service to transform an group of ragtag kids into new heroes at a private academy.  (Sony)
critic_reviews: If August has turned the children in your life into Bored Girl and Fidget Boy, you could find worse ways to keep them entertained.

Zoom suffers from following three "X-Men" movies and "Sky High," but even if it preceded them, it'd still qualify as little more than a cheap, ugly, forgettable footnote to the seemingly endless superhero boom.
Pure Saturday matinee kiddie fodder and this close to going straight to DVD.
Zoom is a movie that would make Dr. Frankenstein proud. Put together with parts from so many other movies, the thing positively clanks.
This tepid comic-bookish comedy should zip through its theatrical run faster than a speeding bullet. It likely won't perform much more superheroically in ancillary venues.

Tim Allen gamely brings some humanity to the role of the retired, powerless hero Captain Zoom, but is thwarted at every turn by bad special effects, slapdash editing, interminable pop-song montages, and a goofy performance by Courteney Cox.

One of the most dismal excuses for family entertainment ever perpetrated by a major studio, this crude, lazy variation on Disney's "Sky High" (2005) revolves around the education of four "special" youngsters at the hands of a washed-up superhero.
Zoom is a C-list production in every possible way, from the actors and the special effects to the music and the script. Even the product placement is completely third rate.
In a feat of dullness quite powerful in its own way, this lifeless family comedy sucks the joy from every joke it touches.
A kid comedy that's been zapped by extraterrestrial suckiness rays.
This comedy drags its feet, while the sappy sweetness will make you wince.

This is a fun, lighthearted movie with a generally positive message.  It has respectable performances from Tim Allen, Courtney Cox, Chevy Chase, and Rip Torn, and features Kate Mara in an earlier role.  The move has decent special effects -This is a fun, lighthearted movie with a generally positive message.  It has respectable performances from Tim Allen, Courtney Cox, Chevy Chase, and Rip Torn, and features Kate Mara in an earlier role.  The move has decent special effects - not amazing, yet pretty much fitting for what the movie is.  This isn't high art.  It's not serious drama, and it's not a big-budget superhero action thriller.  What it is, is fun - if you can remember how to watch a movie and have fun.

An agonizingly bad misfire at being the next big superhero kids flick. Uninspired characters, a derivative plot and a humorless spirit make this Sky High wannabe a near complete disaster.

Humor childish and generally falls flat. Yet, I still found it had some charm Overall:This is not a good movie, but it can be a little charming and fun if you have nothing better to do.
Terrible, terrible movie. So bad it made me want to vomit. Anyone who actually likes this needs to have their head examined.
Why Tim Allen, why? Why do you have to torture us like that? Just retire already. Garbage, pure garbage.
It's too bad they didn't focus and aim the story to a higher age bracket. This one will amuse kids but may seem pretty silly to adults. On the plus side are some terrific special effects.

If "Zoom" came with a parenthetical title, it would be "X-Men for Dummies". But maybe that's too harsh; perhaps, "X-Men for Bedwetters" is more appropriate, which is to say that a small child won't know the difference between If "Zoom" came with a parenthetical title, it would be "X-Men for Dummies". But maybe that's too harsh; perhaps, "X-Men for Bedwetters" is more appropriate, which is to say that a small child won't know the difference between "Zoom" and its more sophisticated predecessor. But if you're not mourning over the cancellation of WB's "Jack and Bobby", bring a kid or stay home. You'll notice right away that the film is hampered by a limited budget(no money to show the original team in action sans comic panels, or visual progress of Zoom's nemesis), and tired "big name" actors(Chevy Chase gets my vote for the most tired). Naturally, the younger actors fare better because their career trajectory is going in a different direction.
A good family move with humor for both adults and kids. It isn't Star Wars, but the movie is fun.
Simply awful. To think Tim Allen could be so bad and do such bad material! 90 minutes was too long.
90 minutes of my life I'll never get back. A complete waste of time, talent and resources. Awful.
It was fine. My daughter enjoyed it, and I didn't fall asleep. I hated Chevy Chase's scenes but enjoyed most of Tim Allen's. The kids weren't too annoying. It was fine.

Wasted potential. The kids were alright, and Tim Allen was half decent wen he was being sarcastic or a slacker, but Cox, Chase and Torn were just annoying and the endless montages lacked any real connective tissue. Sky High was better.
Zoom is lazy, boring and clich√©d at almost every turn. There's almost nothing to recommend about it.
